org.desc: Superbly displayed and comprehensive collection of archaeological material from the site of Morgantina
An excellent and comprehensive display of archaeological material from Centuripe and the surrounding area
CURRENTLY CLOSED
A medium-sized collection from sites in the surrounding area (Calascibetta, Capodarso, Cozzo Matrice, Enna, Rossomanno, Assoro, Pietraperzia, Agira).

A private collection of antique furniture (principally French) and objets d'art of various cultures and periods, displayed in a restored summer house overlooking the Villa del Casale. The owner, Baron Cammarata del Casale, owns the land on which the Roman villa was found. There are numerous beautiful pieces in the many rooms of the museum, and they include a few Roman sculptures and a red-figure Krater (acquired recently during the auction of Versace's collection). The celebrated coin collection was not on display at the time of visit

address.addrLine: Villa delle Meraviglie, S.P.15, Contrada Casale, 94015 - Piazza Armerina (EN)

org.desc: The major part of the collection previously on display here was removed by the Soprintendente and will form part of the collection in the new Piazza Armerina Archaeological Museum. They are left with 2 small display cases: 1 with medieval to early modern pottery; 1 with some ancient pottery including part of a red figure vase. Just a few ancient ceramics in total, but housed in a beautiful ex-Jesuit monastery that is now the communal library

org.orgName: Museo del Territorio e della Cittï¿½ di Piazza Armerina
org.desc: Date of opening as yet unkown

address.addrLine: Palazzo Trigona, Piazza Duomo 20, 94015 - Piazza Armerina (EN)

org.desc: The collection derives entirely from excavations in Contrada Marcato and consists of Neolithic and Bronze Age material, then a break before late Hellenistic, Roman, Byzantine and Arabic material. 10-12 cases in total, neatly displayed with nice signboards

A comprehensive collection from much of the province of Caltanissetta (principally Sabucina, Gibil Gabib, Polizzello, Capodarso, Vassallaggi, Desueri) from settlements, sanctuaries, necropoleis and chance finds. Amazing bronze material and some superb red and black figure vases. The material ranges in date from the Bronze Age to the Byzantine period

Arranged over two floors, the lower floor is devoted to a geographically organised exhibit of material from the site of Gela, and includes some marvellous pieces. The upper floor is split into several discrete sections. A comprehensive display of the coins is preceded by the famous altars found in Bosco Littorale, and a pi-shaped corridor begins with material from the enormous Thesmophorion at Contrada Bitelemi and then runs through material from the territory around Gela in chronological order from prehistory to the Greeks, Romans and Byzantines

The collection contains material principally deriving from 3 sites (Valle Oscura, Monte Balate and Monte Castellazzo). The red and black figure pottery is given prominence in most rooms, although there is a nice display of 3 stele (2 inscribed). The finds date principally to the 6th-4th Centuries BC (mainly from Castellazzo, presumed to be ancient Mytistraton), with a first room of prehistoric material

address.addrLine: Via delle Regione Siciliana, 93010 - Marianopoli (CL) (sign boards in town still indicate the old museum, vacated in 2012)

org.desc: A newly built 2-floor antiquarium with ample study and storage space below. An amazing prehistoric collection is beautifully displayed. All from the surrounding area, mostly excavated by V LaRosa. A varied and beautifully preserved collection, complemented by an upper floor of well-chosen later material (7th century BC through to the Arabic period)
When visited in July 2015 the museum was closed due to structural problems. It was still closed in June 2016.

org.orgName: Area Archeologica e Antiquarium iconografico di Sabucina
org.desc: Has been closed for many years due to structural problems. All of the material previously displayed here is now in the museum of Caltanissetta. It is currently uncertain if this antiquarium will reopen

The collection was opened in 2012, in a restored palace, and has been very neatly presented. The finds come principally from Polizzello and Monte Raffe, with later material from the town of Mussomeli itself. The prehistoric and Iron Age material from Polizzello is complemented by the 5th and 4th centuries BC material from Monte Raffe. NB some of the items on display are copies of objects currently held in other collections (e.g. Palermo, Caltanissetta)
Used mainly for temporary exhibitions; it does not yet have any permanent collection of its own. Currently closed

address.addrLine: Ex Manifattura Tabacchi, Via Garibaldi, 95120 - Catania (CT)

org.desc: Small antiquarium with finds from the site, principally sculpture with some architectural elements

address.addrLine: Greek-Roman Theatre, Via Vittorio Emanuele 266, 95124 - Catania (CT)

org.desc: Antiquarian collection, comprehensive in scope

address.addrLine: Castello Ursino, Piazza Federico II di Svevia, 95121 Catania (CT)

org.orgName: Museo di Archeologia dell'Universita di Catania
org.desc: This museum is principally formed around the personal collection of Libertini, augmented by donations from Paolo Orsi and other individuals. The majority of the material seems to derive from Catania and Centuripe, but there are also finds from Megara Hyblaia and many have no clear provenance (Libertini frequently purchased on the antiquities market, as well as collecting from his own excavations). The ceramics range from prehistoric to medieval, supplemented by inscriptions, antefixes, terracotta altars, strigils, figurines, pinakes and a number of fakes. A great teaching collection

A small collection of finds from sites in the local area, including some beautiful bronzes, a nice coin collection, black painted 5th C Attic, 6th C Corinthian, 6-5th C Ionian, some Hellenistic and some excellent black and red figure attic

A superb local collection in an 11th century castle with excellent views of Etna and the plain of Catania. Neolithic and Bronze age material from various sites in the area; 8th-5th century material (indigenous and Greek) principally from Mendolito; 4-2 C BC material (principally ceramic), Roman sculpture, amphorae etc. The upper floors have modern weapons, paintings and letters.

org.orgName: Antiquarium e museo civico di Aci Castello
org.desc: A very small collection with superb Stentinello pottery, amphorae and anchors (plus fossils and a mineralogical collection)

Small collection of material from sites in the local area, amply covering Neolithic-Bronze-Archaic periods. A few classical and hellenistic-roman pieces, with a nice amphora collection (excellent preservation) and an excellent epigraphic section
Small collection of material from sites in the local area, covering Neolithic-Bronze-Archaic-Classical-Roman periods with some lovely pieces. Excellently displayed
A neatly-displayed collection of material from the excavations at Contrada Terravecchia. Mainly ceramics of 10th-6th centuries BC

address.addrLine: Piazza Carlo Maria Carafa, palazzo comunale, 95042 - Grammichele (CT)

org.orgName: Sala espositiva, area archeologica delle Mura dionigiane di Adrano
org.desc: A small collection of finds from this site was displayed in a renovated 1-room building next to the walls. These were removed to the Castle in Adrano due to safety considerations. The only pieces remaining in June 2015 were some kiln wasters
A very small collection, mostly of sherds (some prehistoric, some archaic) with a few carved blocks (e.g. an Aeolic capital)

A superb collection of ceramics (with a few stone objects) from prehistoric to modern times. Neatly displayed. Much material from the locality, but also from other sites in Sicily (e.g. Agrigento, Sciacca). The majority of the collection is medieval-modern

A single room with 12 display cases containing finds exclusively from the site of Palike, organised chronologically. Predominantly archaic and classical, but extending from Paleolithic to Medieval. A wide range of material, from painted architectural pieces to ceramics, metal objects (including a writing stylus), terraccotta figurines etc.

Several display cases containing well-ordered and very well-lit pieces, mainly ceramics but with some metal and silver objects. Starts with a few cases of Neolithic and Eneolithic objects, passes to 7th century and then classical and hellenistic pieces. Nothing that is much later. The objects all come from necropoleis in the area of Licodia Eubea and excavations carried out in the town itself

org.orgName: Museo Archeologico, del Risorgimento, e pinacoteca Zelantea
org.desc: A small antiquarian collection with some ceramics (strong in oil lamps), a lovely spearhead, 2 axe blades, a bust possibly of Julius Caesar, some inscribed stamps (metal), and a few figurines (both metal and terracotta)

address.addrLine: Via Marchese di San Giuliano 17, 95024 - Aci Reale

org.desc: CURRENTLY CLOSED. It had a small collection of antiquities collected by local fishermen, mainly amphorae, with some anchors, but there was at least one bronze age vessel.

address.addrLine: Piazza Ognina 14,17, 95100 - Via dei Conzari 18 - Ognina (CT)

org.orgName: Antiquarium di Santa Venera al Pozzo
org.desc: Unknown

Beautifully displayed small museum, very well-lit with good descriptions and a well-arranged collection. It begins with a geographical and chronological overview, continues with a focus on the house of the pithos that was excavated and is on display in the archaeological park, then the necropolis, then the later periods (a single small case). Material mainly from 6-4 Century BC, with some later (terra sigillata and arabic) and some earlier (3rd millenium BC). All from sites in the immediate surrounding area

address.addrLine: Via Papa Giovanni XXIII, 95040 - Castel di Judica (CT)

org.orgName: Collezione Archeologica nascosta nella Villa Manganelli Biscari di Viagrande
org.desc: An eclectic collection of antiquities, ranging from large architectural pieces (marble columns, column capitals, architraves) through sculpture (bronze and marble) and ceramics (red figure, black figure, Centuripe ware, numerous shapes, sizes, many fragments, including some superb pieces) to small finds (a great collection of strigils and fibulae) and coins. This was part of the collection of Prince Ignazio Biscari, and was in the house when the current owner bought it sight unseen in 1968. He has permission from the state to retain the collection, and it is recognised as being in his private ownership. The collection is partly in the villa itself, and partly in the gardens and a series of purpose-built structures. The archaeological collection is mixed in with a vast collection amassed by the owner (principally art and sculpture of more modern periods, and weaponry)

address.addrLine: Villa Manganelli Biscari di Viagrande, Via Garibaldi 303, Viagrande (CT)

org.desc: Neatly displayed collection of primarily neolithic material (Diana culture) but also some 6th and 5th century BC Greek material (possibly extending into the 4th century BC). The material mainly derives from Bolze Soprane, Edera and the Tartaraci cave

A very small collection of primarily very fragmentary ceramics, with just one nearly complete cup from the San Cono Piano Notaro culture found in the centre of town. The finds cover the Neolithic to Arabic period, and are neatly displayed. They were all found in surface survey in the surrounding area, or were recovered from excavations in the area

address.addrLine: Via dei Greci 35, 95040 - San Michele di Ganzaria (CT)

org.desc: A small series of display cases containing material from Neolithic to recent times, from excavations in the local area: San Marco, Poggio Monaco, Monte Castellaccio, Poggio Cocola and the Collina Storica. Principally ceramics, with some small finds

address.addrLine: Piazza Martiri dï¿½Ungheria 1, ex Carcere Borbonico, 95047 - Paternï¿½ (CT)

org.desc: An excellent collection of archaeological material from the site of Naxos and the surrounding area, with a particular focus on the temples and on the amphorae and anchors recovered from the sea.

org.orgName: Museo Archeologico Regionale Eoliano "Luigi Bernabï¿½ Brea"
org.desc: The enormous collection is displayed in several neighbouring buildings, each with a particular focus: Prehistory, Prehistory of the minor islands, Epigraphy, Geology, the Classical period and later. The finds come from across the Aeolian islands, under the sea that surrounds them, and from the site of Milazzo on Sicily. One of the 3 largest Sicilian collections, it is truly comprehensive in scope and contains a few finds (e.g. the terracotta tragic theatre masks) that are near unique

A small collection of material excavated between 1979 and 2004 (all material excavated previously is in the Paolo Orsi). Mainly 6-5th century BC from the necropoleis and a sanctuary of Demeter, but also a small domestic quarter. Mostly ceramic with some nice pinakes (similar to those from Lokri)

A medium sized collection dedicated to finds from excavations in Milazzo, mainly from the cemeteries, but also from the inhabited area. A nice prehistoric collection, but the focus is primarily on the 5-4BC to 2,3,4 AD. The ancient tuna vertebrae are given pride of place in one of the rooms.

A small room is dedicated to objects found during the excavations and restoration projects in the Castle of Milazzo. Mainly ceramics and coins with some glass ware. Mainly later, e.g. Norman, Swabian, but there is Byzantine material and at least 1 Roman coin

This collection is dedicated to material excavated at the site of Tindaris, organised by type rather than chronology: ceramics, statues, inscriptions, glass ware and a reconstruction of the scaenae-frons

org.orgName: Antiquarium e sito archeologico di Halaesa
org.desc: Excellent display of material from the site, including lovely sculpture and a superb epigraphic collection

address.addrLine: Contrada santa maria delle palate, 98079 - Tusa (ME)

org.orgName: Museo della cultura e delle Arti Figurative Bizantine e Normanne
org.desc: A beautiful collection in a converted church, mainly consisting of stray finds from around town. An excellent epigraphic collection and some material from wells excavated when the church was converted. A highlight is a so-called Kotabos stand

A converted church with a panoramic view over the surrounding area. A very small collection focused on the mosaics from the Roman villa found at Halaesa, accompanied by info boards from a recent exhibition

org.orgName: Antiquarium e scavi della villa Romana di Marina di Patti
org.desc: A small building on the site, dedicated to the excavations at the villa, with very good explanatory boards. Coin collection (going as far back as 4BC), inscriptions, marble decorative elements, small finds, ceramics, and photos of the excavations while they were being carried out.

Dedicated to the finds from Capo d'Orlando itself, it begins chronologically with some Ausonian period pottery (from the foot of the Madonna mountain in the town), but is mainly dedicated to the finds from the bathhouse of the Villa Bagnoli

address.addrLine: Via Del Fanciullo 2 (ingresso via Nino Mancari), 98071 - Capo D'Orlando (ME)

org.desc: The museum moved from Via Monte 1 in 2010, and is now housed in a recently restored palace built by the Tasca D'Almerita family. The archaeological collection is displayed in random order, with few labels or descriptions. Late material is mixed with early, and although there are a few cases with fragmentary ceramics of various periods and two coins, the focus is on various stones (some architectural, some not).

address.addrLine: Palazzo della Cultura (Palazzo Mastrogiovanni Tasca), Corso Umberto, 1, 98073 Mistretta ME, Italy

org.orgName: Museo Archeologico Bernabï¿½ Brea, sezione di Filicudi
org.desc: A 2-floor building next to the port hosts an ethnographic collection on the ground floor (farming equipment, mill-stones and ship-models) and an archaeological collection on the upper, which is divided into four rooms containing inscriptions, column capitals, pottery and some underwater finds, many of which have been recovered by sport divers, together with some information panels about the sites on the island.

org.orgName: Museo Archeologico Bernabo Brea, sezione di Panarea
org.desc: The collection consists of 2 rooms in a lower-ground floor building. The first contains some small finds and models, the material is predominantly prehistoric. The second room contains some amphorae and an anchor from shipwrecks off Panarea and two inscriptions mounted on the walls

The collection consists of 3 rooms lined with cases, all deriving from the excavations in the internal courtyard of Palazzo Zanca. They begin with the most recent material and progress to the earliest. The material largely dates to the 11-15 centuries AD, but a large Roman public building of monumental construction was uncovered in the earliest layer reached. A single case is devoted to this period, with 9 groups of artefacts in it (fragments of amphora, terra sigilata, crustae, mosaic flooring). Excellent information boards throughout

address.addrLine: Palazzo Zanca, Piazza del Municipio, 98122 - Messina (ME)

org.desc: The collection in the "Casina degli Inglesi" consists of 20 inscriptions, 1 statue, two busts, a few mosaics, a 2nd C AD marble sarcophagus and some modern art

A lovely collection, only part of which is archaeological. When Robert Kitson built the place he excavated into the rock and uncovered a cistern (possibly ancient) and the remains of ancient inhabitation, some of which were subsequently built into his garden features. There are loomweights, ceramics and other small finds, mixed in with a lovely collection of modern art. No provenance given for any of the ancient material, although it is understood to all be from Taormina
Partially reopened following extensive restoration work. Comprehensive collection of archaeological material, predominantly from the West of the island, with an important Etruscan collection.

address.addrLine: Centre of Palermo, Piazza Olivella 24, 90100 - Palermo

org.desc: Superb collection of predominantly ceramic material from Western Sicily. Much from excavations sponsored by the bank, some purchased on the antiquities market, and some loaned by the archaeological authorities in Western Sicily

address.addrLine: Palazzo Branciforte, Via Bara all'Olivella 2, 90133 - Palermo

org.desc: A large and well-displayed collection. It begins with three ante-rooms, in the first of which is a rich display of lithics (mainly Neolithic) from the surrounding area. A display of material from Himera (lion-head spouts from the Temple of Victory and red-figure craters being the principle pieces) and a numismatic gallery then follow before the main room which contains Hellenistic and Roman material from Termini Imerese itself. Small finds, sculpture and inscriptions predominate. The museum collection continues upstairs with non-archaeological material (and a single inscription). The courtyard of the building holds a large collection of architectural pieces and inscriptions

address.addrLine: Via Marco Tullio Cicerone, 90018 - Termini Imerese (PA)

org.orgName: Parco Archeologico di Himera e Antiquarium
org.desc: Excellent collection of archaeological material from the site of Himera and the surrounding area (in particular Settefrati and Cefalu) arranged according to find spot

address.addrLine: Contrada Buonfornello - Termini Imerese (PA) On the hill above the temple

org.desc: An idiosyncratic collection of archaeological material, including some famous pieces. Mainly Attic red and black figure

A two-floor structure, with the public buildings displayed on the ground floor (theatre, temple of Aphrodite, bouleuterion) and the private buildings on the upper floor (archaic house c.500 BC), hellenistic houses, Roman house. Excellent displays of ceramics, tiles, small finds, architectural pieces. Many terracotta inscriptions, and 2 Greek stone inscriptions + 2 Arabic ones

address.addrLine: Contrada Perciana San Cipirello - Monreale (PA) At start of road up to archaeological site of Monte Iato

org.orgName: Area Archeologica e Antiquarium di Solunto
org.desc: There are two museum buildings at the site. The first, at the entrance, gives an overview of the site and its excavations, then treats some of the individual buildings and areas within the site. The inscriptions are here (from the theatre). The second, at the exit, contains the small finds, and begins with the archaic (indigenous and punic layers), then moves to the Hellenistic and Roman periods. There are numerous ceramics, some sculpture, some wall paintings and mosaics

address.addrLine: Via Collegio Romano, 90017 - Solunto Santa Flavia (PA)

org.desc: A mixed collection including geological, archaeological and naturalistic samples (a taxidermy collection dominates, together with a section on the collection of Manna and some lovely fossils). The archaeological collection consists of unprovenanced sporadic finds from the Madonie, mainly worked stone blades (Obsidian dominates), displayed in paper cartons, with some Roman lamps and glass ware. 2 Punic(?) amphorae and 1 anchor stock.

The museum presents material from a Hellenistic necropolis excavated to the east of Polizzi Generosa. It is arranged across two floors, with the upper being stratigraphic and the lower typological. The lower floor was closed for repair when visited. The material in the upper floor is organised by the 5 phases identified during excavation (2nd quarter of 4th century BC to end of 2nd century BC). The material is mainly ceramic (pottery and terracotta figurines), with some astragaloi, strigils, jewellery (rings, fibulae etc)
This is an ethnographic collection, very nicely done, of great interest, but contains no ancient archaeological material

address.addrLine: Via Padre Giorgio Guzzetta, 90037 - Piano degli Albanesi (PA)

org.desc: A large room on the 2nd floor of the building, it contains a wealth of material from sites in the territory of Partinico (which was once much larger than it is now). It is mostly fragmentary, principally ceramic (with an unusual amount of stamped amphorae and tiles). Some glass finds, a number of lithics, a few coins, and 2 fragments of Latin inscriptions

address.addrLine: Corso dei Mille - Palazzo del Carmine 90047 - Partinico (PA)

org.desc: A small archaeological section within a much larger museum with large sections on shells, fish, ornithology, carts and early modern and modern art. The archaeological section is devoted to finds made on the adjacent seabed, consisting mainly of amphorae

address.addrLine: Palazzo D'aumale lungomare Peppino Impastato, 90049 - Terrasini

org.desc: The museum is dedicated to the site of Makella (ancient Marineo) and the sites in the adjoining valley, the ancient Eleutherios (principally Monte Porcara, Pizzo Cannita and Sant'Agata - a Late Roman cemetery). The museum is located in the castle, and uses the large high rooms to great effect. The collection begins with an overview of the excavation and history of exploration of the area, then covers the surrounding sites and moves chronologically and thematically (selections on every day life, religion, warfare) through the site of Makella itself, finishing with displays on the Medieval period and the process of transforming the ruined castle into the present museum. Further rooms have just been renovated and will be opened shortly to host further parts of the archaeological collection

A well organised museum consisting of a large ground-floor room and a courtyard. Copious descriptive panels in the first room accompany the objects found during excavation work carried out here (at the site of Hippana). The main room consists of finds donated to the museum by local benefactors, mainly (it seems) from the necropolis. Predominantly ceramics, although the excavation material also has slingshots, arrow heads etc. from the destruction of the site. The courtyard hosts some carved stone pieces, including one that is inscribed with at least 2 lines of Greek

The museum is arranged both chronologically and thematically, with sections on the early inhabitation of the region and the medieval period bracketing thematic sections on the Entella tablets, the granary, the necropolis, the coins and the inscriptions

Arranged across 2 floors and a series of rooms, the upper floor follows a chronological arrangement beginning with the Neolithic and Bronze Age, the 5-4 century BC site of Montagna Vecchia, then some Hellenistic and Roman finds (including the famous milestone). The lower floor is a lapidarium with some reconstructed pithoi. Several columns and architrave pieces come from 2 Roman peristyle houses
Unknown

org.orgName: Museo Civico della Cultura Artigiana e Contadina
org.desc: CLOSED. Not expected to reopen

org.orgName: Antiquarium dei bagni di Cefala Diana
org.desc: The archaeological material recovered in excavations in the courtyard of the complex will eventually be displayed in a museum in one of the wings of the current building, but there is as yet no date for its opening

address.addrLine: Strada Provinciale 189, presso bivio di Baucinae di Bolognetta, 90030 - Cefala Diana (PA)

org.desc: The archaeological collection is currently in storage prior to display in the Civic Museum. No date has yet been set for its opening

org.orgName: Museo Archeologico Multimediale della Tonnara dell'Orso

org.desc: The archaeological collection is arranged in 4 rooms on the ground floor, and is mainly devoted to 6th and 5th century BC material from the surrounding area. There is some Roman material (principally oil lamps and the 3 inscriptions). One room is entirely focused on the site of Monte Alburchia (from which the 3 inscriptions originate)
Currently closed, no date set for reopening

address.addrLine: Via Vittorio Emanuele III 52, 90025 - Lercara Friddi

org.desc: Exhibition was formed in the early 2000s from chance finds in the area of the necropolis of Hykana (identification not yet confirmed) dating from 7th to 4th centuries BC. The location of the settlement site is not yet clear. The Soprintendenza became involved to stop the Tombaroli and took the material gathered to the Salinas, from which it was returned to Montelepre when a sufficient space was allocated for it. Nicely exhibited, a lovely collection in a series of cases. Principally ceramic, in good condition, some lithic finds.

address.addrLine: Torre Ventimiglia, Vai della Torre 1, 90040 - Montelepre (PA)

org.desc: Closed. Not expected to reopen

A well-displayed and well-lit collection of miscellaneous material collected by Colisano, who lived in Petralia (died in 1990) and collected from across the island. Some has a provenance (Selinunte, Bagheria, Kamarina) but most is "provenance unknown". It has a wide scope, from Neolithic through Bronze age, and plenty of material from the Archaic, Classical, Hellenistic and Roman periods. There are coins, ceramics, terracotta sculptures and bronzes. There is a comprehensive display on the Grotta del Vecchiuzzo (which Colisano rediscovered)
Comprehensive collection of archaeological material discovered in the province of Ragusa, with a particular focus on the sites of Kaukana, Kamarina, Castiglione and Monte Casasia

A small but relatively rich collection of material from the area around Vittoria. Some are labelled as being from Camarina, some from closer to the museum. There is an inscription, some pottery, some coins and a few other miscellaneous objects. The collection has been declared and gifted to the state, and it is hoped that it will soon be moved to a building designed specifically for it
Comprehensive collection of archaeological material discovered at the site of Kamarina

Excellent collection of archaeological material from Modica and the surrounding area - as far as Scicli - with one or more cases devoted to each site. A lot of prehistoric material, some classical and Byzantine, and a good faunal collection (including shark teeth found near Modica) Very well arranged and organised, across a series of rooms. The undisputed highlight is the bronze Herakles of Cafeo

The small collection is held in a cave on the site, with 4 display cases (2 ancient; 2 Norman). The ancient material includes Castellucio pottery, Licodia Eubea phase pottery from the 8th century, and some material from the Archaic to Hellenistic periods. There is then a chronological break before the Norman material. Some nice medieval church pieces and 2 x 17th century AD inscriptions

3 display cases contain material exclusively from Monte Casasia, with excellent descriptive boards. Displayed in a beautiful palazzo together with an ornithological collection, they have an agreement with the Soprintendenza to augment the collection with numerous other pieces currently in storage in Ragusa. The best material from this site will, however, remain on display in Ragusa museum

An outstanding collection of archaeological material. The collection ranges from Siracusa and the surrounding territory (Megara Hyblaia, Akrai, Kasmenai etc) to encompass all of eastern Sicily, reaching as far as Gela and Agrigento. The ground floor covers prehistory through to the end of the Classical period. Upstairs includes Hellenistic and Roman Syracuse and a display of material from the catacombs. A gallery displaying material from Hellenistic eastern Sicily is in preparation.
An excellent art museum: Room 1 contains some material dated to the 6th century AD
A small collection of architectural pieces recovered from the Temple.

The museum was damaged in an earthquake and all the ancient archaeological material was sent to the Paolo Orsi for safe keeping. They have not yet been returned and the collection currently consists of stones from various medieval buildings, some medieval armour and weaponry, and 2 ancient inscribed blocks
Tiny collection of objects from the site, particularly the temple, together with models and explanatory boards

address.addrLine: Site of Akrai,Colle dell'Acromonte, 96010 - Palazzolo Acreide (SR)

org.desc: This museum displays the part of the Barone Judica collection that was previously in Lentini. Mostly unprovenanced, it is well-displayed in a well-restored building. Mostly thought to come from Akrai itself. The ceramics are of good quality, but heavily abraded. 6 stone inscriptions plus a terracotta altar & a charcoal inscription on ceramic.

address.addrLine: Palazzo Cappellani, Via Gaetano Italia - Palazzolo Acreide (SR)

org.desc: The collection is arranged across two floors, beginning with Bronze Age material from the surrounding area and then focusing on thematic displays of the Greek and roman city (sacred areas, fortifications etc). The finds are overwhelmingly ceramic, but there is an inscribed lead tablet and some vase inscriptions. The upper floor displays bronze age finds from several sites in the surrounding area and some underwater finds from Punta Castelluccio
CURRENTLY CLOSED

The archaeological collection is housed in one long room that has been subdivided into 4 discrete areas containing 25 cases and a series of open displays. 1 case contains pre- and proto-historic material, 3 are for material from Selinunte, 1 Camarina, 8 Erice, 1 Mozia, 1 Birgi, 1 Lilybaeum, 1 Centuripe, 4 contain material of unknown origin, 1 mixed sites, and then 1 for Punic stamped amphora handles, 1 for Greek and Roman stamped amphora handles, and 1 for Latin epigraphy. In addition there are open displays of material found on the seabed (amphorae, anchor parts, a Roman ram from the Aegadi Islands battle), a large two-sided Latin inscription and a section on Arabic and later Jewish inscriptions

A small collection in a lovely setting. The roof-top terrace has a pointer to show the location of the Battle of the Aegates islands, and the ground floor has a nice but small collection of pottery and helmets found under the sea in this region. Some lovely sign boards for the tower and underwater archaeology in the area
Comprehensive collection of Archaeological material discovered at the site of Mozia and in the surrounding area

address.addrLine: Isola di Mozia, Contrada Spagnola, Birgi, 91025 Marsala (TP)

org.orgName: Museo archeologico regionale Lilibeo Marsala - Baglio Anselmi
org.desc: Comprehensive collection of Archaeological material discovered at the site of Lilybaeum and in the surrounding area

The satyr is beautifully displayed alongside other finds made in the "Sicilian Channel". These consist of amphorae, anchor parts, assorted ceramics, and two "codices" of leather (probably 18th century AD), as well as a single, possibly Punic, inscription, and the Bronze elephant leg.

address.addrLine: Museo Civico, Ex-Collegio Gesuiti, Piazza Plebiscito 91026 - Mazara del Vallo (TP)

org.desc: A rich but small collection of finds from the site and area of Selinunte
A beautifully displayed collection of predominantly prehistoric material from Contrada Stretta and the surrounding area, displayed in a lovingly restored Norman castle

org.orgName: Stabilimento Florio delle Tonnare di Favignana e delle Formiche
org.desc: A small but rich collection of material found on the adjacent seabed.

address.addrLine: Ex Stabilmento Florio delle Tonnare di Favignana e Formica, Via Amendola, 29, 91023 Favignana (TP)

org.desc: The archaeological collection consists of a small coin collection, a few catapult/ballista balls, some ceramics (a small prehistoric section) a small bust of venus and an inscription; good display boards with a description of the battle of the Aegates islands. This is the totality of the archaeological collection, which is supplemented by further rooms containing medieval and modern art & arms and weaponry. Further inscriptions are in the entrance to the library of Erice

The neatly displayed material principally derives from the personal collection of a Librarian of Marsala (Salvatore Struppa) who also become honorary inspector of antiquities of the region. The ceramics mostly derive from early Lilybaeum (4-2 centuries BC) some architectural pieces and uninscribed cinerary urns. A stretch of 5th century AD road has been excavated and is on display in one room, and an entire room is given over to 8 Latin inscriptions from Lilybaeum

address.addrLine: Via Ludovico Anselmi Correale - Complesso Monumentale San Pietro , 91025 Marsala (TP)

org.desc: A selection of architectural pieces of various dates is scattered on the floor around the outer parts of the church, with no labels or information of any kind. The centre of the church is given over to 6 display cases containing finds from several contrada around Mazara

address.addrLine: Chiesa di San Bartolomeo, Piazza San Bartolomeo, 91026 Mazara del Vallo (TP)

org.desc: A Baglio once belonging to the Florio family has been repurposed as a museum space, with two wings currently in use. The West wing houses results from the recent Marconi excavations focusing on the temples on the Acropolis and their early history. There is plenty of space for expansion. The north wing focuses on the German led excavations in the settlement area. Many information panels complement the comprehensive range of material (architectural, ceramic etc)

address.addrLine: Parco Archeologico di Selinunte, Via Selinunte, Castelvetrano

org.orgName: Museo delle Trame Mediterranee della Fondazione Orestiadi
org.desc: A stunning museum mainly given over to Islamic and Modern Art, that begins with a small room containing some archaeological material (Bronze age to 6th-5th century BC). The later material is mainly Greek in origin (Lekythos, cover of a Lekane, kylikes etc) so perhaps from Selinunte, but no provenance is given for any of these pieces

A series of rooms contain material from Mokarta, Monte Polizzo and the castle in Salemi itself. Nice 13-10th century BC material from Mokarta; indigenous, Elymian and Punic from Monte Polizzo. The material from the castle is well chosen and displayed
Unknown

A great teaching collection for prehistoric cultures, with some material from the surrounding area supplemented by finds from Northern and Southern Africa and copies of several famous finds (e.g. Venus of Willendorf) The focus is on the Palaeolithic, and they also use comparative material from e.g. Zulu cultures to illustrate specific points. There is a nice display on the Levanzo grotto and a few other areas. This material was originally in Trapani at the Torre de Ligny, and was moved here when that facility was closed. The collection is Medium in size, but the Sicilian material and non-copies alone would be classed as small
Has been closed on all 3 visits made to date

address.addrLine: Via Savoia 57, 91010 - San Vito Lo Capo (TP)

org.desc: The museum is located on the first and second floor of the tower attached to the Tonnara at Bonagia. It is a museum of tuna fishing, but also contains 11 amphorae and a few lead anchor parts

address.addrLine: P.za Tonnara I - 91010 Tonnara di Bonagia (TP)

org.desc: Comprehensive collection of archaeological material discovered at the site of Agrigento and in Agrigento province, organised both by chronology and type across a number of rooms and corridors

address.addrLine: Contrada San Nicola, 12 Valley of the Temples, 92100 - Agrigento (AG)

org.desc: A small archaeological collection: primarily carved lapidary pieces from churches that have been demolished. 4 small cases of ancient pottery from the territory and from a private collection, and a small collection of amphorae found underwater. A fine ethnographic collection on the upper floor
Comprehensive collection of archaeological material discovered at the site of Monte Adranone

address.addrLine: Palazzo Panitteri, Piazza Vincenzo Navarro, 92017 - Sambuca di Sicilia (AG)

org.desc: An unusual collection of finds, seemingly all chance surface discoveries, from 4th millenium BC to Arabic times, on display in a unique environment that has to be seen to be believed: the roof space between the top floor vaults and the roof of the building

The collection has been recently redisplayed and renovated, and is a superb example of the museological tradition in Sicily. Maps and information boards provide context for well chosen pieces from the surrounding region. The first few rooms are organised chronologically and by site, with an occasional focus on particular object categories (e.g. Obsidian). They begin with the Neolithic and proceed through the Bronze age and Archaic periods before the main room (which concentrates on ancient Phintias) which looks at the acropolis, urban topography and domestic quarters. A room underneath the main room displays the famous golden jewellery and coins found in Phintias
This collection is now closed and it is not expected to reopen

address.addrLine: Collina dei Templi (Giunone, Concordia e Ercole). Valley of the Temples, 92100 Agrigento (AG)

org.desc: A small series of display cases contain material exclusively from the site of Heraklea Minoa. Mostly from the necropoleis, but also from the excavated houses. Mostly Archaic and Hellenistic, with some red figure pottery. The key find is a large bone aulos

address.addrLine: Area archeologica e Antiquarium Eraclea Minoa, Contrada Minoa, 92011 - Cattolica Eraclea (AG)

org.orgName: Museo Civico di Pisa e Guardi
org.desc: A small collection begins with some 19th century (AD) terracotta figurines and progresses to 3 further rooms containing finds from the surrounding area, with some neolithic and eneolithic and 9-6 century BC material. Some of the best finds from the area are now in the museum in Milena (prior to the formation of this museum, when Sig Palumbo of Milena was inspector for this region). The terracotta house models are particularly nice. Finishes with a carved stone lintel from a Byzantine church. Well lit and displayed, with excellent information panels

A lovingly restored palazzo houses the well-displayed personal collection of the local nobleman, Francesco Scaglione (furniture, paintings, art, archaeological objects, objets d'art, small architectural pieces, coins, medals, butterflies etc. The archaeological material is restricted to three cases: (1) amp; (2) mainly ceramics from 5th-3rd centuries BC but some Roman lamps and a Byzantine piece (3) ancient coins from all over the island. No provenance given for ceramics

A very small collection of material found in the thermal cave complex below the antiquarium, some of which are copies (the originals being in the Regional Archaeological Museum in Agrigento). Two cases: (1) Eneolithic and Neolithic material (2) Greek and Roman. There is a lovely display of the cave complex and another case with the equipment the modern explorers have used in their work

org.orgName: Museo Storico (full name: istituzione culturale Federico II)
org.desc: A small collection with a focus on the Portopalo shipwreck, the finds from which are in the adjacent storeroom. There are some neolithic stone blades in one case, but otherwise it is Roman period material

Dedicated entirely to finds from the site of Monte Saraceno on the outside of town. Begins with a very small selection of Castelluccio pottery and then moves directly to 7th-6th century BC material. Spread over two large rooms, highlights include a satyr-donkey vase, an Attic vase with a sacrifice scene, an Otre in the shape of a tortoise amp; two Archaic Greek inscriptions. A splendid collection

A restored courtyard adjacent to a church hosts an info point, a small library and the archaeological museum (which complements the Museo Civico 50m down the road). The collection consists of a selection of the material collected by Dr Johannes Bergemann's survey in the area, together with chance finds previously held in private collections in the town. There is also a small mineralogical collection. Coins, ceramics (various periods) and some small metal implements

A thoughtfully displayed collection of material relating to the creation and use of Papyri in the ancient world, with a natural focus on Egypt. It is a rich collection, and a lot of care and attention has been put into its display

Closed. BUT, the Chiesa di San Francesco di Paolo (which hosts a permanent exhibition on Sicilian popular art and traditions) has a small temporary display of material from the Badia Vecchia: several Roman sculptures, some painted plaster fragments and some decorative elements from various ancient buildings. All from Taormina

address.addrLine: Palazzo Badia Vecchia, Via Circonvallazione 30, 98039 - Taormina (ME)

org.desc: The collection is focused on finds made within the city of Messina itself (the warship ram from Acqualadroni being one of the only notable exceptions). Beginning with the prehistoric periods (a single case) it progresses through the different areas and periods of the city, focusing at the end on the sculpture and inscriptions. The accompanying boards set the objects into a clear historical context. One of the highlights of the collection is the aforementioned warship ram. Two other objects given prominence are two of the four Oscan inscriptions in the collection, from the time of Mamertine domination. The principle display cases focus on the cemeteries and religious areas of the city. The grounds of the museum contain a number of monuments and architectural pieces (many from the post-medieval city that was destroyed in the 1908 earthquake) but some earlier as well, principally Roman in date

There are 2 collections here at the moment (1) one of the most perfect and extensive Malacological collections in the world (2) a neat and modern display of archaeological material (entitled from Village to Palace) excavated in and around Menfi. There is a lot of 10th-13th centuries AD material, but also a lot of Late Roman material from the cemeteries. Mostly ceramics, with few dates, but otherwise lengthy descriptions. It is intended that the building will eventually house other exhibits, in particular the Portopalo shipwreck once it is studied and published.

address.addrLine: Palazzo Pignatelli, Piazza Vittorio Emanuele III, 92013 - Menfi (AG)

org.desc: A 2-floor museum in a small palazzo. The lower floor hosts a geological collection and the prehistoric material (one small room with a couple of cases). The upper floor contains a series of cases holding material from the Archaic period tombs (11-7 centuries BC) excavated by Orsi et al

address.addrLine: Auberge de Provence, Republic Street, Valletta VLT 1112, Malta

org.desc: Site of the ancient settlement of Helorus

org.orgName: Area archeologica della Neapolis, Orecchio di Dionisio e Teatro Greco
org.desc: Archaeological park, containing the Greek theatre, altar of Hieron, Roman amphitheatre, and ancient stone quarries.

The collection consists of 2 rooms, one focusing on the site of Contrada Margi, and the other on the site of Terravecchia. A series of finds are displayed in small cases, some of which are quite late (e.g. a particularly nice collection of 10th century AD rings)

address.addrLine: Palazzo Barone, Via XX Settembre, 97010 Giarratana (RG)

org.orgName: Museo Civico di Santa Marina Salina
org.desc: A small collection, beautifully displayed in a building constructed specially for it. The majority of the finds are from the Roman Bath at Contrada Barone and the Middle Bronze Age village of Portella
A small collection of archaeological material found in the area of Leni, principally from the sites of Rinicedda, Val di Chiesa and Punta Megna

The antiquarium contains numerous information panels and a small collection of objects recovered during the various excavations campaigns carried out in the region of the Castello. The finds are disparate in nature, ranging from carved stones (including a ?marble? sundial), coins, a Hellenistic Iron helmet with bronze studs, a roof tile, small ceramics and a large collection of arrowheads. A carved relief of a catapult is given pride of place. No inscriptions are currently displayed in the antiquarium, but a monumental text is located nearby.

address.addrLine: Contrada Santa Maria delle Palate, Tusa, ME

org.desc: The museum is housed in a 16th century monastery, and is arranged across rooms. The first room looks at sites from around the area (Terravecchia and Monte Riparato). The second room has later material from the site of Caltavuturo vecchio. The third room is dedicated to Monte Riparato (small finds, mosaic, Greek inscription) some 7th century BC, but mainly 4th and 3rd, and some Samian ware. The final room is given over to the numismatic collection, the focal point of which is a Republican coin hoard found in the area

address.addrLine: Museo Civico "Don G. Guarneri", Piazza San Francesco nï¿½1, Caltavuturo, 90022 PA

org.desc: Site of a Greek colony founded 728 BC, destroyed 483 BC, redeveloped in the fourth century BC and sacked by Rome in 213 BC.
The entrance hall to the civic library in the municipio hosts a small collection of sculpture and inscriptions, 2 of which are ancient

address.addrLine: Via Vittorio Emanuele, 1, 91016 Erice TP, Italy
75 Varick Street, 11th Fl New York, NY 10013
The Fitzwilliam Museum Trumpington Street, Cambridge CB2 1RB
Heberden Coin Room Ashmolean Museum Beaumont Street Oxford OX1 2PH

org.desc: Site of Ancient Apollonia

A very large and rich well-displayed civic museum with a strong focus on the lifestyle and life experience of people in this region in the 19th and 20th centuries. A large natural history section includes a single case related to human interaction with the environment, half of which is archaeological. There is some Castelluciano period pottery, and some stamped Roman pottery from a small settlement at the foot of the hill of Niscemi

A 3 room museum, the first 2 of which are ethno-anthropological with a strong section on WWII. The 3rd room is devoted to the archaeology of the area with 5 display cases of finds from Valcorrente (Neolithic and Chalcolithic), Grammena (Hellenistic to Late Roman & Byzantine). Some nice finds and good explanatory material.

address.addrLine: Casa Giallo Russo-Giusti, Via II Retta Levante 173, 95032 - Belpasso (CT)

org.orgName: Museo Archeologico Santi Furnari di Tripi
org.desc: The neatly-curated collection derives entirely from the Hellenistic necropolis of ancient Abakainon on the outskirts of the modern town of Tripi. The high acidity of the soil has stripped many of the ceramics of their surface decoration, and there is an understandable focus on the metal items (gold and iron) and the stone stele and moulded bases. The collection is arranged over 4 rooms and one corridor on two levels of a restored palazzo, and is equipped with a number of IT panels

This well-displayed museum is dedicated to the so-called Temple of Victory at Himera and the recently excavated West Cemetery material. A well-made video introduces the history of the site and focuses in particular on the two battles. Excellent illustrations and information boards contextualise all of the finds. The large building has been subdivided into discrete rooms by low walls and panels, and the superb material from the cemeteries are juxtaposed neatly with architectural elements from the Temple. The displays include material from the medieval and modern strata that overlaid the Temple

address.addrLine: Contrada Buonfornello (PA) On the plain next to the temple

org.desc: A single room in a larger building, all the material derives from Soprintendenza excavations at the site of Monte Maranfusa just outside of the present town. 7 cases with some amphorae etc on open view. Mostly ceramics (amphroae, household ware, loom weights) but also a case of metallic small finds (bronze astragalos, clothing fibulae etc)

A single case of archaeological material found by Christiane Reimann on her property, on display in one of the ground floor rooms. Storage vessels, coins, miniature terracotta figurines, oil lamps, tile fragments etc

org.orgName: Museo Civico di Mazara del Vallo
org.desc: A museum devoted to amphorae found in the waters off Mazara del Vallo, spread across a series of rooms in the ex-Jesuit monastery, in one of which a small excavation has been opened, which is juxtaposed with some of the amphorae

address.addrLine: Piazza del Plebiscito 2, 91026 - Mazara del Vallo (TP)

org.desc: The Ground and first floor of the castle has been renovated as a small museum, with separate entrance to each level. The first floor is given over to the history of the town and area; room 1 a brief history; room 2 photographs of archaeological finds from the Grotta del Cavallo of Monte Inici and some fossils; room 3 has a series of cases and open exhibits of archaeological material found principally in the sea (amphorae, anchor parts, pot covers, a terracotta figure) mainly of 2nd BC to 5 AD

address.addrLine: Castello Arabo-Normanno, Piazza Castello, 91014 - Castellammare del Golfo (TP)

org.orgName: Museo della Preistoria del Valle del Belice
org.desc: A beautiful collection displayed in 3 rooms with an ante-room containing panels giving geological and chronological background. The collection is principally the lithic material found in the Valle del Belice, dating to 300,000 BC to 1000 BC. The material is the best of its kind in Sicily; the final room has 2 Roman amphorae, a case of proto-Elymian ceramics, and then 2 cases of late Roman finds from a nearby site including an Arabic sugar pot (this is not officially open, so should be listed as such)

A well displayed collection of finds made in the waters of Agrigento province. One focus is on the 17-18th century AD wreck at Bottazza, but there are also ancient remains such as amphorae, a Montefortino type helmet, and some finds (mostly ceramic, but also a ring-key) from the mouth of the Akragas river at San Leone

address.addrLine: Collina dei Templi (Giunone, Concordia e Ercole). Valley of the Temples, 92100 Agrigento (AG)

org.desc: The collection has been bought on the international antiquities market with the permission of the Soprintendente, and is mainly displayed in the lobby of the hotel. Other pieces are on display in one bedroom, with further pieces due to be displayed in other rooms currently under completion. The few items are well displayed, with excellent labels, and consists of numerous ceramics (including red and black figure examples, and a terracotta figurine) as well as a bone gaming dice, arrow heads and a bronze dagger
